title: Initiation & Response
description: Explore how you approach initiating intimacy and responding to your partner.

questions.text: When it comes to initiating intimacy, I tend to...
choices: Initiate often—I'm comfortable making the first move
Wait for signals that my partner is interested
Prefer my partner to initiate most of the time
Initiate sometimes, but I like it mutual

therapeutic.rationale: Initiation patterns shape intimate dynamics. Frequent-initiators take the lead; signal-readers watch for cues; prefer-receiver types are more passive; mutual-seekers share responsibility. Imbalanced initiation creates resentment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The frequent-initiator may feel undesired if always pursuing; the prefer-receiver may never feel safe to initiate. Talk about what's behind your pattern.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched initiation patterns create balance. You'll share the responsibility naturally.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel about initiating intimacy? What makes it easy or hard for you?

questions.text: How I prefer my partner to initiate is...
choices: Directly and clearly—I like knowing
Subtly with hints and buildup
Through physical closeness that escalates
By creating a romantic mood first

therapeutic.rationale: Initiation preferences affect reception. Direct-lovers want clarity; hint-lovers enjoy subtlety; escalation-lovers like gradual buildup; mood-setters want romance first. Mismatched styles mean missed signals.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The direct-lover may miss subtle hints; the hint-lover may find directness unsexy. Learn your partner's style and adjust your approach.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched preferences make initiation smooth. You'll naturally approach each other in appealing ways.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's the most appealing way for your partner to initiate? What turns you off?

questions.text: When my partner isn't in the mood after I initiate, I tend to feel...
choices: Understanding—it's not personal
A little disappointed but okay
Rejected even if I know I shouldn't
Fine as long as we connect in other ways

therapeutic.rationale: Rejection response reveals attachment security. Understanding types don't personalize; disappointed-but-okay types feel it but recover; rejection-feelers struggle with no; connection-seekers redirect. How you handle 'no' affects your partner's safety to say it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The rejection-feeler's pain is real, but making your partner feel guilty for saying no creates pressure. The understanding partner can help the rejection-feeler feel safe.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared rejection response means you understand each other's experience on both sides.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when your partner says no? What would help you feel okay about it?

questions.text: I want my partner to feel safe saying 'not tonight' because...
choices: Genuine desire matters more than obligation
Pressure ruins the experience for both
I want honesty in our relationship
All of these—consent is foundational

therapeutic.rationale: Values around freely-given intimacy reveal relationship health. All these reasons are valid and important. Partners who feel safe saying no feel safe saying yes enthusiastically.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: These are all good reasons—different emphasis is fine. The key is creating genuine safety for both yes and no.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared values around consent create safety. You both prioritize freely-given intimacy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How important is it that your partner feels completely free to say no? Does your behavior match that value?

questions.text: The ideal balance of who initiates would be...
choices: Roughly equal between us
Whoever feels it more in the moment
Mostly my partner—I prefer responding
Mostly me—I'm comfortable leading

therapeutic.rationale: Desired initiation balance reflects preferences about roles and dynamics. Equal-sharers value mutual effort; in-the-moment types are flexible; response-preferers are more passive; leader-preferers enjoy initiating. Articulating this prevents resentment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different preferences need negotiation. If both prefer responding, neither initiates. If both prefer leading, you may compete. Find your workable balance.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared ideal balance makes planning your dynamic easier. You agree on how initiation should flow.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What balance of initiation would feel right to you? Is that what's happening now?
